title: Mutual cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes through vacuum field
abstract: Two types of resonance between the spontaneous emissions by two- and single photon transitions of three inverted radiators from the ensemble are proposed to accelerate the collective decay rate of the entangled photon pairs generated by the system relative the dipole-forbidden transition. One of them corresponds to the situation when the total energy of emitted photons by two dipole-active radiators enter the two-photon resonance with the dipole-forbidden transition of third atom. Second effect corresponds to the scattering situation, when the difference of the excited energies of two dipole-active radiators is in the resonance with the dipole-forbidden transition of third atom. These effects are accompanied with the interferences between single- and two-quantum collective transitions of three inverted radiators from the ensemble. The three particle collective decay rate is defined in the description of the atomic correlation functions.

motivations: There is a need to accelerate the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs generated by a system of inverted radiators.
Understanding the cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes can lead to improved control over the emission properties of such systems.
objectives: Investigate the mutual cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes through vacuum field in a system of three inverted radiators.
Explore the role of resonance between spontaneous emissions by two- and single-photon transitions in accelerating the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs.
methods: Propose and analyze two types of resonance between spontaneous emissions by two- and single-photon transitions of three inverted radiators.
Use atomic correlation functions to describe the three-particle collective decay rate and investigate the interferences between single- and two-quantum collective transitions.
results: Accelerate the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs generated by the system relative to the dipole-forbidden transition.
Gain insight into the cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes and their impact on the emission properties of the system.
llama_json.research_subject: Cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes in a system of inverted radiators

motivations: There is a need to accelerate the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs generated by a system of inverted radiators.
objectives: Propose two types of resonance between the spontaneous emissions by two- and single photon transitions of three inverted radiators to accelerate the collective decay rate.
methods: Investigate the situation when the total energy of emitted photons by two dipole-active radiators enter the two-photon resonance with the dipole-forbidden transition of third atom.
Examine the scattering situation, when the difference of the excited energies of two dipole-active radiators is in the resonance with the dipole-forbidden transition of third atom.
results: The proposed resonances can potentially accelerate the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs.
openai_json.research_subject: Mutual cooperative effects between single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes through vacuum field

motivations: Understanding the interaction between single- and two-photon transitions in quantum systems is crucial for advancing quantum optics and photon emission control.
The collective decay processes of entangled photon pairs from dipole-forbidden transitions need to be accelerated for practical quantum applications.
objectives: Investigate resonance mechanisms between spontaneous emissions from two- and single-photon transitions in three-atom systems.
Demonstrate how collective quantum effects can enhance the decay rate of entangled photon pairs from dipole-forbidden transitions.
methods: Analyze two types of resonance conditions involving energy matching between dipole-active and dipole-forbidden transitions in three-atom ensembles.
Study the interference effects between single- and two-quantum collective transitions using atomic correlation functions.
Develop theoretical framework for three-particle collective decay rates in the context of cooperative quantum processes.
results: Identification of resonance conditions that accelerate the collective decay rate of entangled photon pairs relative to dipole-forbidden transitions.
Demonstration of interference effects between single- and two-quantum collective transitions in three-radiator systems.
Establishment of a theoretical description for three-particle collective decay rates through atomic correlation functions.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Cooperative quantum effects in single- and two-photon super-fluorescent processes
